title: Like 'Caesar': leadership gripes all around in tired Canberra
text:
But the main fireworks this week have been inside the Nationals, where a group of MPs spoke about getting rid of deputy leader Bridget McKenzie.

Dissent began last week when Senator McKenzie speeded up a dairy industry code of conduct to placate One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, who had been agitating on behalf of dairy farmers.

The code would give them more market power in dealing with milk processors. It was a Nationals initiative but One Nation claimed the credit.

This provoked fury among Nationals MPs, especially Queenslanders, who had been lobbying to introduce the code.

Former leader Barnaby Joyce poured cold water on leadership talks on Tuesday but said there was frustration among the Nationals, be it over the dairy issue or being sidelined by the Prime Minister on drought.

‘‘What the Nationals get upset with is we drive an agenda, we do so much work in a space, then obviously if Pauline Hanson comes out and announces it, it’s not that she developed the policy, it’s not that she drove the agenda – we did,’’ he said.

‘‘We were driving forward with that, and the ultimate outcome was that a National party minister has brought this about. Not an independent senator. A National party minister broad the dairy code about.’’

Advertisement

But Senator McKenzie and leader Michael McCormack were safe, he said.

‘‘You’ll wait forever before the Nationals spill a leader,’’ Mr Joyce said.

‘‘They don’t do that. It doesn’t happen. So Bridget has my support. Michael has my support.’’

Even inside the Liberal party, there is some discontent with what MPs say is an increasingly dictatorial style of Mr Morrison.

One described the Prime Minister as ‘‘Caesar’’.

Morale in Labor remains low and there is some low-level quibbling from some MPs about Albanese’s leadership.

‘‘There’s a dangerous level of sullenness in the party at the moment’’ said one.

Advertisement

But many more said that apart from a bit of dissent, ‘‘not a single person is saying we should do something’’.

Mr Albanese used his address to caucus to reinforce the decision to back legislation enabling free trade deals with Indonesia, Hong Kong and Peru, which has caused friction with sections of the union movement.

"There are a lot of 55-45 calls in this job but this was not one of those, it was a good outcome,'' he said.

Outwardly, the Coalition was on track on Tuesday night to chalk up another success in parliament. Labor was poised to wave through the lower house the big stick legislation, which will allow the forced divestment of energy assets of companies found to be engaging in anti-competitive conduct.
description: At the end of a long and arduous year, low-level grumbling about leadership is gnawing away at the major parties.
